Description: Four copper beads in the form of rings: one is described by the excavators as 'of thin metal ribbon wound up spirally to form a ring'; the shape is Brunton's 86W3. The three others are quite different: 'a thick strip of copper, rectangular in section, was bent round in a flat circle till the ends touched, thus forming a ring.' The first method is the usual one of Predynastic times; the second is apparently new.
Curator's comments: For the shape of Brunton's 86W3, see G. Brunton & G. Caton-Thompson, ‘The Badarian Civilization’ (London, 1928), Bead corpus, pl. I. Bibliography: G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 37, 51, 52; pl. XXII, 38; Grave register, pl. VIII; Bead corpus, pl. XXXIX, 86W15; The British Museum, ' A General Introductory Guide to the Egyptian Collections in the British Museum' (London, 1964), 24; A. Wilkinson, 'Ancient Egyptian Jewellery' (London, 1971), 11.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (27)
